conclusion: Determine the speed of the elevator at t = 60 seconds by analyzing the acceleration-time graph.
The speed of the elevator is the integral of the acceleration over time.
Identify segments of the graph: t = 0 to 1s, acceleration increases from 0 to 2 m/s².
From t = 1 to 4s, acceleration is constant at 2 m/s².
From t = 4 to 5s, acceleration decreases from 2 m/s² to 0.
From t = 55 to 56s, acceleration decreases from 0 to -2 m/s².
From t = 56 to 59s, acceleration is constant at -2 m/s².
From t = 59 to 60s, acceleration increases from -2 m/s² to 0.
Calculate area for segment 1 (t = 0 to 1s): Area = 1 m/s.
Calculate area for segment 2 (t = 1 to 4s): Area = 6 m/s.
Calculate area for segment 3 (t = 4 to 5s): Area = 1 m/s.
Calculate area for segment 4 (t = 5 to 55s): Area = 0 m/s.
Calculate area for segment 5 (t = 55 to 56s): Area = -1 m/s.
Calculate area for segment 6 (t = 56 to 59s): Area = -6 m/s.
Calculate area for segment 7 (t = 59 to 60s): Area = -1 m/s.
Sum the areas to find total change in velocity: Total = 0 m/s.
The speed of the elevator at t = 60 seconds is 0 m/s.
